content: <articles>    <article xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink/">   <front>     <article-meta>       <title-group>         <article-title>Hot Stars with Cool Companions</article-title>       </title-group>       <contrib-group>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Kraus</surname>             <given-names>Adam</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>University of Texas</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Dodson-Robinson</surname>             <given-names>Sarah</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>University of Delaware</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Gullikson</surname>             <given-names>Kevin</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>University of Texas</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>       </contrib-group>       <pub-date pub-type="pub">         <year>2014</year>       </pub-date>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/10584"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://www2.lowell.edu/workshops/coolstars18/"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/10584/files/Poster.pdf"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/10584/files/Poster.png?subformat=icon-90"/>     </article-meta>     <abstract><p>We present intermediate results of a spectroscopic survey for late K-M companions orbiting nearby A and B type stars. Such companions may have formed in the massive disk of the young primary star, and so may be scaled-up versions of brown dwarfs formed in the disks of less massive stars. In addition, the multiplicity of these bright and young A and B type stars is important to generate samples for adaptive optics planet searches. The method we use to search for companions has a uniform detection threshold for any companion within about 2-3&quot;, and so is complementary to ongoing imaging surveys. We find companion stars with a variety of masses, giving early indication that these companions <em>do not</em> form through gravitational disk instability, which would preferentially produce low-mass stars.</p></abstract>   </front>   <article-type>user-cool-stars</article-type> </article>   </articles>
